WRITING.TEXT: Which is exactly why I love stand up comedy. It's my own little safe space away from PC culture.

Well that's a strawman if I've ever seen one. How is not baking a cake for a gay wedding comparable to the murder of human beings?
And actually there are a lot of discrimination laws in place and currently lots of businesses have gotten in a lot of trouble for not serving certain kinds of people.
Are you saying that if someone starts up a private business, they should be forced to serve customers and should not be able to decide that they don't want to serve somebody? We're not talking about emergency medical care here. We're talking about baking a cake for somebody. Why should you have to serve somebody you don't want to? It's not like they wait for the person to pay and then don't give them service. They just decide that they aren't going to take that person's money.
Hipster is just shorthand for "anything I don't understand and don't like."
Gotta get that le 90's kid cred!!
Please tell me what advantages being fat has in modern living?

If you live in an area where every fucking business around is horribly bigoted and won't serve certain kinds of people, I don't think it's ridiculous to say that maybe you should move. I'm a straight white man and no way in hell would I live in an area that banned gays or banned Muslims or banned anyone on the basis of race, religion, gender etc. from using their business. I am also pretty sure this town would have absolutely no economy at all and it would be widely publicized as one of the worst places in America.
Edit: I'm saying yes, it's awful for businesses to discriminate like this and they shouldn't do it. However, I don't think any business should be legally required to serve anybody. Name one business that has openly discriminated against certain kinds of people and didn't lose business because if it. By nature, these kinds of places will suffer economically from discriminating. You decide as a business you won't serve gay people? They're just gonna go to your competitor then. And if you happen to live in a fictional part of America where your kind of people are not taken well at all and businesses everywhere don't wanna serve you, I don't see why you would want to stay there anyways.
Then you chose the wrong area to live in. Move. Or bake your own cake.
Lol yep heard that line about 20 times. Watched him plummet to his death off the cliff by the graveyard. So satisfying.

I think the biggest lesson learned from dark souls is that actions have consequences. You entered a boss fight before preparing? Say goodbye to all the humanity and souls you just acquired. Attacked an NPC? Have fun getting killed over and over again.

WRITING.TEXT: I have been using zweihander +5 for the most part but I'm finding in confined spaces it doesn't do too well because it keeps hitting walls so for that I use halberd +5 with a shield in my left arm. Is it a waste to do this? I'm trying to do a strength build.

I mean yeah of course I'll agree with you that Rick isn't such a good guy either. He's always had the attitude of shoot first, think second. The difference is that Rick doesn't seem to enjoy the killing. If Rick were to decide someone had to die, he'd shoot them. He wouldn't bash someone's brains in with a bat and smile the whole time doing it. He also wouldn't burn half of someone's face in front of everyone...and he sure as hell wouldn't force every woman he wants to be one of his wives and taunt the men they were with.

He's psychologically manipulating people. The only seemingly good things Negan does is really for manipulation purposes. He just wants to continue doing whatever the hell he feels like and that means not being cruel all of the time. Negan obviously enjoys toying with people, harming them and killing them. Clearly a psychopath, but he's not an idiot. He knows he's gotta throw people a bone here and there to keep them happy.
Yes Negan is doing a lot of these awful things to maintain authority and to keep things going smoothly, but I don't see how he isn't a bad guy. What does he use his power for? He fucks all the women he wants, he humiliates people and he brutalizes and/or kills anyone who misbehaves. He hasn't shown that he's doing what he does to make the world a better place. You're falling for an obvious villain trope.

I guess you're right. I just felt a lot more stressed and overwhelmed in the Oblivion final battle, and really felt immersed with all the Daedra attacking the imperial city. I felt more like I was trying to save the world.

You didn't think the whole scheme to get into Camoran's Paradise was cool? And then fighting off hordes and hordes of Daedra in the imperial city and having Martin turn into the avatar of akatosh was cool? No you didn't get to fight Dagon one-on-one, but clearly he'd obliterate you with no effort. I guarantee you if you remade the final part of the game on Skyrim's engine, it would absolutely demolish Skyrim's ending.

Exactly. I wanted to rp a character that had a strong curiosity about the world and cared about truth and understanding above all else. The blades are the total antithesis to that, so it was frustrating to have to work with them so much. I just wanted to hang out in High Hrothgar and talk philosophy with Paarthurnax and pretty much become a Greybeard.

Alduin was just a harder dragon fight, and when you spend the entire game killing dragons it's really a disappointment. After playing and beating Oblivion, which has such an epic final battle, Skyrim's ending was just lackluster. There wasn't really anything special about the Alduin fight.

Good episode, phenomenal acting by the characters, but I have to say that I still don't think the cliffhanger was worth it and I'm annoyed at how they didn't show right away who it was. Believing that Jesus was God in the flesh, that he performed miracles and that he rose from the dead and saved us all from sin with absolutely no evidence is seen as a respectable belief, but believing Bigfoot exists makes you insane. I'm not trying to be edgy, but I'm really baffled as to why we give religious beliefs special treatment even though they are no more plausible than belief in Bigfoot.
